content: Ideal wallet: Just ask the user how much they are willing to pay for a fee.  It doesn't matter what the current going rate is at all, only thing that matters is user's willingness to pay.

author: madeof_tin7509

author: sky.cactus
content: The *right* question to ask the user is "how much are you willing to pay" *without* context.

author: sky.cactus
content: The context leads to cognitive bias and a wrong answer.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: Given (B) here, I actually think the best UX is to simply not give any choices at all and just make an assertion to the user.

author: sky.cactus
content:
"Your transaction will cost between $0.10 and $0.20."
Decline.  Accept.

author: sky.cactus
content:
If we believe users *want* to make decisions, I think we should ask them the context-free question of willingness to pay.
If we believe users don't want to make decisions, I think we should just assert the fee range to them.

content: If the max you are willing to pay is lower than the current fee will your transaction get rejected or can it linger until fees have come down and you get included?
